pageTextData.title: Porcelain of ancient China
pageTextData.description: The porcelain of the Ming Dynasty of China (1368-1644 CE) benefitted, as did other arts, from the economic success of the 15th century CE, in particular, and the consequent surge in demand for quality handcraft production both at home and abroad. The Ming dynasty is rightly famous for its fine ceramics and especially the cobalt blue-and-white porcelain produced in such towns as Jingdezhen in Jiangxi province. Still highly prized by collectors today, Ming porcelain would have a major influence on the ceramics of many other countries from Japan to Britain.

pageTextData.title: Bronze vase
pageTextData.subTitle: Ming Dynasty, Xuande reign period, AD 1425-1435
pageTextData.description: Bronze vase, double gourd form. The main portion, of oval section, having a large panel on each side with dragons and clouds in sharp relief; two loop handles with vertical bands of engraved floral ornament below each. Raised Xuande mark on upper part.

pageTextData.title: Flower pot
pageTextData.subTitle: Ming Dynasty, AD 1436-1464
pageTextData.description: Flower cultivation and arrangement were popular pastimes amongst wealthy people in Ming period. Flowers were potted and put in vases in interiors and in gardens, forming miniature landscapes modelled on landscape paintings. As with other objects for elite hobbies, there were rules depending on your rank as to the size of planters and where they should be positioned in the home, and so on.

pageTextData.title: Wine-storage jar
pageTextData.subTitle: Ming Dynasty, Tianshun reign period, AD 1457-1464
pageTextData.description: This meiping shows a scholarly immortal (one who lives forver) against a background of undulating clouds. His servants are painted on a smaller scale than their master, following Chinese painting convention. One carries a zither (qin) wrapped in material. The qin was the ultimate instrument for a Chinese intellectual, which he would ideally play in a beautiful landscape.

pageTextData.title: Vase or candleholder
pageTextData.subTitle: Ming Dynasty, Zhengde reign mark and period, AD 1506-1521
pageTextData.description: The base of this vessel bears the reign mark of the Zhengde emperor, but the inscription on the body says 'Preserve our faith from danger' in Persian. It may have been used by the Zhengde emperor, who was fascinated by foreign scripts. But it was probably made for the Muslim eunuchs of Near Eastern descent. They were powerful during this time, and were able to get porcelain made for their exclusive use in the Imperial kilns.
